media_caption: Graciano Lopez Jaena, Literary figures during the Spanish period
text_description: "Fray Botod" by Graciano Lopez Jaena (1856-96), an anticlerical satire, appears in Discursos y Articulos Varios in Barcelona.
“Elias” by Rosauro Almario (1886-1933), generally believed to be the first Tagalog short story, is published in Mithi.
Ang Maikling Kuwentong Tagalog 1886-1948, edited by Teodoro A. Agoncillo (1912-85), is published, containing some of the best writing done in Tagalog during the first half of the 20th century.

media_caption: La Solidaridad, dated 15 Sep 1894, a periodical that served as an outlet for reformist writings
text_headline: Rizal’s essay “Filipinas dentro de Cien Años” appears in La Solidaridad.
text_description: Rizal’s essay “Filipinas dentro de Cien Años” appears in La Solidaridad.

media_caption: Title page of the 1760 edition of the first Tagalog pasyon by Gaspar Aquino de Belen
text_headline: The Mahal na Pasion ni Jesu Christong Panginoon Natin na Tola by Gaspar Aquino de Belen is published.
text_description: Gaspar Aquino de Belen publishes the earliest pasyon, a long verse narrative on the Passion of Christ titled Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Cristong Panginoon Natin na Tola, which is set to octosyllabic quintillas. It appears as an addendum to his translation of a Spanish devotional work.

media_caption: Title page of the 1899 edition of El Filibusterismo
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Leon Gallery Fine Arts and Antiques)
text_description: Rizal's El Filibusterismo is published in Ghent, Belgium, and is later smuggled into the Philippines through Hong Kong.

media_caption: Isabelo de los Reyes, Literary figures during the Spanish period
text_description: Isabelo de los Reyes (1864-1938) publishes El Folk-lore Filipino, a two-volume, pioneering collection of folklore materials. An English translation will be published in 1994.
Deogracias Rosario publishes “Kung Magmahal ang Makata,” considered by some as the first “munting kasaysayan” or short story in Buntot Pague.
The first edition of Philippine Prose and Poetry, the first high school textbook to use only Filipino writings, is published.
An Parabareta, a weekly Bikol newspaper carrying essays, poems, and stories, begins publication.
Don Pagusara’s (b. 1938) Qontrapuntal, notable for poems that critique local literary practices and for erotic poems, is published.

media_caption: Title page of Salvador P. Lopez’s Literature and Society, 1940, which defines writing as social commitment
text_description: Literature and Society by Salvador P. Lopez, which advocates "proletarian literature," is published.

media_caption: Francisco Coching, El Indio, 1952
text_description: Pilipino Komiks is published by Ramon Roces. It will serialize El Indio by Francisco V. Coching (1919-98), which will be reprinted as a graphic novel in 2009 by Vibal Foundation. Other komiks magazines will emerge in the 1950s and 1960s.

Emmanuel Torres' Shapes of Silence, which includes "Another Invitation to the Pope to Visit Tondo," is published. It reflects the shift to more socially conscious and even politically critical writing among many Filipino writers during the martial law period.

media_caption: Dekada '70 by Lualhati Bautista, 1988, Social realist literature
media_credit: (Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection, University of the Philippines Press, and Anvil Publishing, Inc)
text_description: Lualhati Bautistas (b. 1945) martial law novel Dekada 70, also known for one of the earliest articulations of feminism in contemporary Philippine literature, is published.

media_caption: Vicente Sotto, Poets in the native languages, Cebuano
text_description: “Maming” by Vicente Sotto (1877-1950), considered the first Cebuano short story, is published in Ang Suga.
Cebuano writer Sulpicio Osorio (1898-1970) publishes an anticlerical novel, Mga Bungsod nga Guipangguba.

Rebellious group of young Tagalog writers led by Clodualdo del Mundo Sr (1911-77) and Alejandro G. Abadilla (1906-69) founds Kapisanang Panitikan, or Panitikan, seeking to introduce modernism in Tagalog poetry. They start publication of a literary magazine called Panitikan.
Gumer Rafanan’s (b. 1931) novel Ang Misteryo sa Inuslang Kasingkasing begins to be serialized in Bisaya.

media_caption: The Peninsulars by Linda Ty-Casper, 1964
media_credit: (Capitol Publishing House, Bookmark, Inc, and Erehwon)
text_description: Forces of the British Empire occupy Manila and the port of Cavite until 1764. Dawsonne Drake of the British East India Company is appointed as the British Governor of Manila. The occupation will inspire the novel The Peninsulars by Linda Ty-Casper (b. 1931), the first of her many historical novels.

media_caption: Lidia, Juan Crisostomo C. Soto, 1907, Romantic novel in Kapampangan
media_credit: (Don Honorio Ventura Technological State University- Center for Capampangan Culture and the Arts, Ang Kapatid ng Bayan, and Ninoyc)
text_description: The novel Lidia by Juan Crisostomo Soto (1867-1918), the first prose narrative of its kind in Kapampangan literature, noted for a developed degree of realism, is published.

media_caption: Clodualdo del Mundo’s Mula Sa Parolang Ginto, one of the notable surveys and studies of Philippine literature in Filipino during the 1960s
text_description: Mula sa Parolang Ginto by Clodualdo L. del Mundo, one of the first compilations of literary criticism in Tagalog, is published.
Staffers of Ilonggo weekly magazine Kasanag form Sumakwelan, seeking to unify all Ilonggo writers and to enrich the Ilonggo language, with Ramon Munzones (1913-92) as its first president.
William Faulkner visits the Philippines.
Textanaga and Dalitext are published, attesting to the influence of new media in the production and circulation of literature.

media_caption: Crisalidas, Fernando Ma. Guerrero, 1914, Books of poetry in Spanish
media_credit: (Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library and Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)
text_description: Crisalidas, by Fernando Ma. Guerrero (1873-1929), the “maestro” by a generation of Filipino writers in Spanish.

media_caption: Zoilo M. Galang’s A Child of Sorrow, 1921, made into a movie in the 1930s
media_credit: (Abiva Publishing House, courtesy of Thea Barachina)
text_description: The first Filipino novel in English, A Child of Sorrow by Zoilo Galang (1895-1959), is published.

media_caption: Si Nena at si Neneng, Valeriano Hernandez Peña, Early Tagalog novels by Valeriano Hernandez Peña and Iñigo Ed. Regalado
media_credit: (Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library and Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)
text_description: Continuing the didactic tradition set by Urbana at Feliza, the novel Nena at Neneng by Valeriano Hernandez-Peña (1858-1922) is serialized; it will become the first Tagalog novel to be published in book form in 1905.

media_caption: Benjamin, Angel Magahum, Early Ilonggo novel by Angel Magahum, 1920
media_credit: (University of Michigan and National Commission for Culture and the Arts)
text_description: The first known Ilonggo novel, Benjamin, Novela con Panuguiron nga Binisaya by Angel Magahum (1867-1935), is published.

media_caption: El Renacimiento, Politically oriented periodical
media_credit: (Biblioteca Nacional de España, University of Michigan, and UP Diliman Main Library)
text_description: The editorial “Aves de Rapiña,” which denounces “a man, who, besides being like the eagle, also has the characteristic of the vulture, the owl, and the vampire,” appears in El Renacimineto. Dean Worcester, Secretary of the Interior, files a libel case against the periodical and eventually wins.

media_caption: Buak nang Ester by Aurelio Tolentino, 1911, Pre-World War II novel written in local language
media_credit: (Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection and University of the Philippines Press)
text_description: Aurelio Tolentino (1867-1915) publishes Ing Buac nang Ester, a Kapampangan novel which employs Victorian and gothic elements.

media_caption: Ang Tundo Man May Langit Din Nobela ni Andres Cristobal Cruz, 1959, Social realist novel
text_description: Liwayway will serialize many important novels, including Ang Tundo Man May Langit Din (1959-60), Daluyong (1962-63), and Canal de la Reina (1972-73).

media_caption: 1995 reprint of Jose Corazon de Jesus’s Sa Dakong Silangan, originally published in 1928
text_description: Sa Dakong Silangan by Jose Corazon de Jesus, an allegorical narrative poem denouncing Spanish and, later, American imperialist interests, is published.

media_caption: Members of the Aklatang Bayan, a Tagalog writers’ group, including Lope K. Santos, Patricio Mariano, Severino Reyes, Carlos Ronquillo, and Julian Cruz Balmaseda, ca 1930
media_credit: (Dictionary of Philippine Biography by E. Arsenio Manuel. Filipiniana Publications, 1955.)
text_description: Aklatang Bayan, an organization of Tagalog writers, is established in Tondo, with Rosauro Almario as president.

media_caption: Liwayway,1948, The Ramon Roces line of magazines
text_description: Liwayway is founded and will become the most widely read Tagalog magazine.

media_caption: Florentino Collantes, left, and Jose Corazon de Jesus, the most famous “kings” of balagtasan, ca 1930
text_description: The first balagtasan, a poetic oratorical joust, is held in Manila; it is between Jose Corazon de Jesus and Florentino Collantes (1896-1951). Balagtasan in Spanish will later be held, between Jesus Balmori (1887-1948) and Manuel Bernabe (1890-1960), and poetic debates in other Philippine languages will develop, like the crissotan in Kapampangan and the bukanegan in Ilocano.

media_caption: Novel in Spanish during the American period by Antonio M. Abad, 1929, published in English translation in the year 2013
text_description: La Oveja de Nathan by Antonio M. Abad (1894-1970), which critiques the effects of American imperialism, is published. The novel will be reprinted with an English translation in 2013.
Ernest Hemingway visits the Philippines.
Lubas sa Dagang Bisaya (LUDABI), the largest organization of writers in Cebuano, is established in Cebu City."

media_caption: Kenkoy ni Tony Velasquez, Liwayway, 1929, First comic strip in the Philippines written and illustrated by Antonio Velasquez and published in Liwayway, 1929
text_description: The first Kenkoy comic strip is published in Liwayway, popularizing the form in the Philippines. When its writer Romualdo Ramos dies in 1932, Tony Velasquez (1910-97), its illustrator, takes over until the series ends in 1961. Kenkoy is antedated by Kiko at Angge, published in Telembang between 1922 and 1924, written by Tagalog novelist Iñigo Ed. Regalado (1888-1976) and illustrated by Fernando Amorsolo (1892-1972).

media_caption: Amado V. Hernandez, a poet in his native language Tagalog
text_description: Ilaw at Panitik, a literary society, is founded in Manila by Buenaventura Medina (1896-1966), Remigio Mat. Castro (1887-1944), and others, with Deogracias Rosario (1894-1936), Jose Corazon de Jesus (1894-1932), and Amado V. Hernandez (1903-70) as members.

media_caption: Magdalena Jalandoni, Poets in the native languages, Ilonggo
text_description: The novel Ang Bantay sang Patyo by Magdalena Jalandoni (1891-1978), known as the “Grand Old Lady of Ilonggo Literature,” is published.

media_caption: Arturo Rotor, fictionist in English
media_credit: (CCP Collection and Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library)
text_description: Arturo Rotor publishes “Zita,” a story showing the influence of Wilbur Daniele Steele, in the Philippines Free Press. Along with “Footnote to Youth” by Jose Garcia Villa, it will be named the best short story of the year. Rotor’s stories will be collected in The Wound and the Scar in 1937 and in The Men Who Play God and Other Stories in 1990.

media_caption: Work influenced by motifs from Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo by Lazaro Francisco, 1997 reprint
text_description: Lazaro Francisco (1898-1960) serializes Bayang Nagpatiwakal, a novel of social criticism after Rizal’s Noli and Fili, in Alitaptap. The novel is revised and is published as Ilaw sa Hilaga in 1947-48.

media_caption: Angela Manalang Gloria, Writers in English, poets
media_credit: (CCP Collection and Mr. and Ms. Collection, Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library)
text_description: Angela Manalang-Gloria (1907-94) publishes Poems, arguably the first feminist collection of poems in English. It includes the controversial “Revolt from the Hymen.”

media_caption: Salvador P. Lopez for his essay “Literature and Society”, Winners of the 1940 Commonwealth Literary Awards
media_credit: (Jaime C. Laya Collection and CCP Collection)
text_description: The Philippine Writers League is organized, with Federico Mangahas (1904-79) and Salvador P. Lopez (1911-73) as president and vice president, respectively. It organizes a writers conference and the Commonwealth Literary Contest, through which it champions literature with social consciousness, against the Art for Art’s sake philosophy identified with Jose Garcia Villa.

media_caption: Genoveva Edroza-Matute, awarded in 1992, Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Panitikan) awardees
media_credit: (CCP Collection, BJ Patiño, and Ricardo Lee/Jerry Siapoc)
text_description: Genoveva Edroza-Matute publishes her first short story, “Walong Taong Gulang,” in Mabuhay Extra, introducing readers to a writer adept in channeling a child’s psyche. Her stories will be collected in Piling Maiikling Kuwento 1939-1992 in 1992.

media_caption: How My Brother Leon Brought Home A Wife, Manuel E. Arguilla, 1940, Collections of short stories in English
media_credit: (Philippine Book Guild, Cellar Book Shop, and Ateneo Institute of Literary Arts and Practices)
text_description: How My Brother Leon Brought Home a Wife by Manuel Arguilla, known for capturing “local color” in his stories, is published.

media_caption: Salvador P. Lopez for his essay “Literature and Society”, Winners of the 1940 Commonwealth Literary Awards
media_credit: (Jaime C. Laya Collection and CCP Collection)
text_description: The Commonwealth Literary Awards, the first state-sponsored literary contest, are given. Apart from Arguilla’s story collection and Lopez’s essay collection, other winners include “Like the Molave” by R. Zulueta da Costa (1915-1990), and “Mi Casa de Nipa” by Jesus Balmori. Both will be published in 1941.

media_caption: Cecilio Apostol, Notable Filipino writers in Spanish
text_description: Pentelicas, by Cecilio Apostol (1877-1938) is published.

media_caption: Carlos P. Romulo, 1982, National Artist for Literature
text_description: For “his observations and forecasts of Far Eastern developments during a tour of the trouble centers from Hong Kong to Batavia,” Carlos P. Romulo receives the Pulitzer Prize for Correspondence.

media_caption: Cuentos De Juana, Adelina Gurrea, 1943, Published folk tale
text_description: Adelina Gurrea (1904-71) publishes Cuentos de Juana, a collection of short stories set in a Negros sugar plantation at the turn of the 20th century and featuring creatures from native folklore in Madrid.

media_caption: The UP Writers’ Club including, seated from left to right, Manuel Arguilla, Federico Mangahas, Salvador P. Lopez, English teacher Robert Conklin, Fernando Leaño, Fidel de Castro, and Vicente del Fierro
media_credit: (Fernandez and Alegre 1984, Cultural Center of the Philippines)
text_description: A group of UP students, including Casiano Calalang (1906-82), Loreto Paras (1908-2008), Arturo Rotor (1907-88), Paz Latorena (1908-53), and Jose Garcia Villa (1908-97), forms the UP Writers’ Club. Its official publication, founded in the same year, is the Literary Apprentice.

media_caption: Hiligaynon (Ilonggo), one of the lines of magazines by The Ramon Roces
text_description: Hiligaynon becomes an important outlet of Western Visayas writing. Among the writers it will publish are Ramon Muzones (1913-92), Conrado Norada (1921), Magdalena Jalandoni (1891-1978).

media_caption: Bannawag (Ilokano), one of the lines of magazines by The Ramon Roces
text_description: Writers published in Bannawag will include Juan S. P. Hidalgo (b. 1936), Gregorio Laconsay (1932-2007), and Marcelino Foronda (1926-96).

media_caption: Have Come, Am Here by Jose Garcia Villa, Jose Garcia Villa’s books published in the United States
text_description: Have Come, Am Here by Jose Garcia Villa is published in New York, making him a celebrity in the American literary scene and cementing his reputation in the Philippines. He is nominated for the Pulitzer Prize but loses to Robert Frost. He will typify later expatriates writing largely for an American or Western audience.

media_caption: Francisco Arcellana, 1990, National Artist for Literature
text_description: The Philippine Review and Pillars publish the works of Francisco Arcellana (1916-2002), Nick Joaquin, and Kerima Polotan (1925-2011), among other writers using English.
Dark Hours by Conchitina Cruz (b. 1976), with poems that make use of devices like marginalia and footnotes, is published.

media_caption: Ang 25 Pinakamabuting Maikling Kathang Pilipino ng 1943, Compilation of winning short stories in Tagalog during the Japanese Occupation
text_description: Ang 25 Pinakamabuting Maikling Kathang Pilipino ng 1943 is published. It collects the entries to a contest sponsored by the Manila Sinbun-sya, the cultural arm of the Japanese government in the Philippines, whose aim is to eradicate traces of Western culture in the country.

media_caption: Philippine Magazine, Publications which became outlets for writings in English
text_description: Philippine Magazine, edited by A. V. H. Hartendorp, begins to be published. It was formerly the Philippine Teacher (1904); then, Philippine Education (1906); then, Philippine Education Magazine (1926). It will publish many stories that will be considered classics of Philippine literature in English, including “Midsummer” by Manuel Arguilla (1911-44), “Tandoz” by Delfin Fresnosa (1916-88), and “Hunger in Barok” by N. V. M. Gonzalez (1915-99).

media_caption: Alejandro G. Abadilla’s Parnasong Tagalog, one of the notable surveys and studies of Philippine literature in Filipino during the 1950s
media_credit: (Limbagan ng Dalubhasaang Epifanio de los Santos)
text_description: A landmark anthology of Tagalog poetry, opening with Balagtas, Parnasong Tagalog, edited by Alejandro G. Abadilla, is published.

media_caption: Jose Garcia Villa, poet in English
media_credit: (CCP Collection and Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library)
text_description: Alberto S. Florentino (b. 1931) launches the Peso Books, which, priced at one peso a copy, seeks to popularize Philippine literature, starting with Jose Garcia Villa’s Poems 55.

media_caption: Edith L. Tiempo, awarded National Artist for literature in 1999
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: The first Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature is held. It is limited to the short story in English and in Tagalog. The winners are “Clay” by Juan Gatbonton (b. 1928), “The Flowers of May” by Francisco Arcellana, and “The Black Monkey” by Edith Tiempo (1919-2011).

media_caption: Mga Piling Akda ng Kadipan, 1965, a publication of one of the key literary groups in the 1950s
text_description: KADIPAN (Kapisanang Aklat, Diwa, at Panitik), which will hold literary contests for work published in school papers, is established by students of Manuel L. Quezon Educational Institution (later University).

media_caption: Prose and Poems by Nick Joaquin, 1952, Philippine literature in English
text_description: The short stories, poems, and a novella of Nick Joaquin are published in Prose and Poems, portraying the Filipino as a creature caught between conflicting historical forces. Joaquin’s later stories will be collected in Tropical Gothic (1972).

media_caption: Ako'y Isang Tinig by Genoveva Edroza-Matute, 1952, Collection of literary works by Genoveva Edroza-Matute, 1952
text_description: One of the earliest single-author collections of Tagalog short stories, Genoveva Edroza-Matute’s Ako’y Isang Tinig, is published.

media_caption: Edith L. Tiempo, awarded National Artist for literature in 1999
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Six Filipino Poets, edited by Leonard Casper, is published, evincing the ascendancy of formalism in Philippine poetry in English. Represented are Amador T. Daguio (1912-66), Dominador I. Ilio (1913-2006), Oscar de Zuniga (1912-69), Carlos A. Angeles (1921-2001), Edith L. Tiempo, and Ricaredo Demetillo (1920-98).

media_caption: A Season of Grace by N.V.M. Gonzalez, 1956, Novel in English
text_description: N. V. M. Gonzalez serializes A Season of Grace, notable for being told from the point of view of a kaingero and for catching the rhythm of the local dialect in English, in Weekly Women’s Magazine.

media_caption: Lope K. Santos, a poet in his native language Tagalog
text_description: Lope K. Santos’s landmark study Ang Apat na Himagsik ni Balagtas, which reads Florante at Laura as a political text critical of the Spanish colonial regime, is published.

media_caption: Magnificence and other stories, Estrella D. Alfon, 1962, Philippine literature in English
text_description: “A Fairy Tale for the City” by Estrella Alfon (1917-83) is published in This Week. Alfon is sued for obscenity, and the court bans the reprinting of the story. Her other stories will be collected in Magnificence and Other Stories in 1960.

media_caption: Bannawag (Ilokano), one of the lines of magazines by The Ramon Roces
text_description: Bannawag begins the serialization of Constante Casabar’s (1929-2000) Ilocano novel Dagiti Mariing Iti Parbangon, a love story set in crime-ridden 1950s Ilocos and a social commentary on Ilocano politics.

media_caption: Perfil de Cresta by Manuel Bernabe, 1957, Posthumous collection of works in Spanish
media_credit: (Mr. and Ms. Collection/Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library and Biblioteca Virtual Miguel de Cervantes)
text_description: The Spanish poems of Manuel Bernabe (1890-1960), the “king of balagtasan in Spanish,” are collected in Perfil de Cresta.

media_caption: Silliman National Writers’ Workshop, 1966
text_description: Patterned after the Iowa Writers Workshop, the inaugural Silliman Writers Workshop, founded by Edith and Edilberto Tiempo (1913-96), is held in Dumaguete City. Similar workshops will be established in the University of the Philippines, the Ateneo de Manila University, and other institutions.

media_caption: The Butcher, the Baker, the Candlestick Maker by Gilda Cordero-Fernando, 1962
text_description: The Butcher, the Baker, the Candlestick Maker by Gilda Cordero-Fernando (b. 1932) is published, offering portraits of the middle class Filipino woman. Cordero-Fernando will venture into publishing books on national identity and heritage.

media_caption: Ravens in Love, 2002, a publication of one of the key literary groups in the 1950s
text_description: A group of English writers from UP including Hilario Francia (1929-2003), S. V. Epistola (1925-2004), Virginia Moreno (b. 1925), and Alejandrino Hufana (1926-2003), forms the Ravens, with N. V. M. Gonzalez as mentor.

media_caption: Amador Daguio, post-World War II writer in English
text_description: Amador Daguio (1912-66) makes an English translation of the Ifugao epic Hudhud hi Aliguyon, as chanted by Hinayup Bantayan. It will be published in Epics of the Philippines in 1983.

media_caption: You Lovely People by Bienvenido N. Santos, 1955, Collection of modern short stories in English
text_description: You Lovely People by Bienvenido Santos, chronicling the condition of the Filipino exile in America, is published; it includes his most well-known story “Scent of Apples.”

media_caption: Francisco Arcellana, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1990
text_description: A number of Francisco Arcellana’s stories, including “The Mats” and “Flowers of May,” are collected in Selected Stories.

media_caption: Ricardo Lee, Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Panitikan) awardee in 2015
media_credit: (CCP Collection, BJ Patiño, and Ricardo Lee/Jerry Siapoc)
text_description: Ricardo Lee (b. 1948) gathers his best writing in several genres, including screenplay, short story, essay, feature article, and interview, in Si Tatang at ang Himala ng Ating Panahon.
The Pangasinan novel Samban Agnabenegan by Maria Magsano (1883-1969), which follows a marriage wrecked by infidelity, is published.

media_caption: Leonard Casper’s The Wounded Diamond, a literary criticism in English that emerged in the 1960s
text_description: The Wounded Diamond: Studies in Modern Philippine Literature by Leonard Casper (1923-2018), a collection of critical essays that apply the New Criticism to the works of 29 Filipino writers, is published.

media_caption: Dugo sa Bukang-Liwayway by Rogelio Sicat, 1965, Work influenced by motifs from Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo
text_description: Liwayway begins the serialization of Dugo sa Bukang Liwayway by Rogelio Sicat, aka Rogelio Sikat, which takes off from Rizal’s El Filibusterismo. It will be reprinted as a book in 1989.

media_caption: Antonio Manuud’s Brown Heritage, a literary criticism in English that emerged in the 1960s
text_description: Brown Heritage: Essays on Philippine Cultural Tradition and Literature, a collection of pioneering studies on a broad range of topics in Philippine culture, the first of its kind, is published.

media_caption: Kerima Polotan, post-World War II writer in English
text_description: Stories: A Collection by Kerima Polotan is published. It includes “The Sounds of Sunday,” winner of the Asia Magazine literary prize and the germ of her novel The Hand of the Enemy (1962).

media_caption: Kung Wala na ang Tag-araw, Ano Ngayon, Ricky? By Rosario De Guzman-Lingat, A work of fiction using psychological realism
text_description: Rosario de Guzman Lingat (1924-94) publishes her first novel, Kung Wala na ang Tag-araw, a complex psychological study of an adulterous man.

media_caption: Amado V. Hernandez, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1973
text_description: Jose Garcia Villa and Amado V. Hernandez are declared National Artists.

media_caption: Edith L. Tiempo, awarded National Artist for literature in 1999
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Edith Tiempo’s first poetry collection, The Tracks of Babylon and Other Poems, is published.

media_caption: Bembol Roco and Hilda Koronel in Lino Brocka’s Maynila: Sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag, 1975, a film adaptation of Edgardo M. Reyes’s novel, Sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag
text_description: Liwayway begins serialization of Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag by Edgardo Reyes (1936-2012), notable for its dark portrayal of urban life.

media_caption: Bituen Ti Rosales by Juan S.P. Hidalgo, Jr., 1969, collection of fiction written in Ilocano
text_description: Juan S. P. Hidalgo Jr publishes a collection of Ilocano short stories, Bituen ti Rosales ken Dadduma Pay a Sarita.

media_caption: Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas (UMPIL) members, with National Artists for Literature Virgilio S. Almario seated fourth from left
text_description: The Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas (UMPIL) holds its first meeting at the Social Security System Building in Quezon City, with Adrian Cristobal (1932-2007) as the organization’s first chairperson.
Bamboo and the Greenwood Tree: Essays on Filipino Literature in English by Miguel A. Bernad (1917-2009), one of the first collections of criticism on Philippine literature in English, is published.
Davao, Reconstructing History from Text and Memory, Macario Tiu’s (1948) account of Davao history, indigenous groups, myths, and legends, is published.

media_caption: Volume Five of the Maranao Darangen, published in 1988
text_description: The first three volumes of Sr. Maria Delia Coronel’s translation of Darangen, the epic of the Maranao, is published.

media_caption: Carlos P. Romulo, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1982
text_description: Carlos P. Romulo is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Bikols of the Philippines, 1983, Scholarship on regional literary materials
text_description: Bikols of the Philippines by Maria Lilia F. Realubit (b. 1940) is published.

media_caption: Balagtasismo Versus Modernismo, Virgilio S. Almario, 1984, Work of literary history
text_description: Balagtasismo versus Modernismo, Virgilio Almario’s study of two schools of Tagalog poetry, is published.

media_caption: Bienvenido Lumbera’s Tagalog Poetry 1570-1898, 2001, a survey of Tagalog poetry during the Spanish colonial period
text_description: Tagalog Poetry, 1570-1898 by Bienvenido Lumbera (b. 1932), an expansive and pioneering critical text on the development of Tagalog poetry, is published.

media_caption: Mga Piling Kuwentong Sebuwano by Marcel M. Navarra, 1986, Regional collection of fiction
text_description: Twelve short stories of Cebuano writer Marcel Navarra (1914-84) published between 1930 and 1955 are collected in Marcel Navarra: Mga Piling Kuwentong Sebuwano, one of the first titles in the Panitikan series, an attempt by three university presses to reprint and translate classic Philippine literary works written in the different Philippine languages.

media_caption: Great Philippine Jungle Energy Café, Alfred A. Yuson, 1988, Work of metafiction
text_description: “Great Philippine Jungle Energy Café” by Alfred Yuson wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the novel. It will be published in 1988.
The first compilation of Tagalog essays, Mga Piling Sanaysay, edited by Alejandro G. Abadilla, is published.
Marne Kilates’s (b. 1952) Mostly in Monsoon Weather and Other Poems is published.
“Unang Ulan ng Mayo” by Ellen Sicat wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.

Kapatid Ko ang Aking Ina by Elena Patron (b. 1938) is serialized. With this her first novel, she becomes one of the first women to break into the male-dominated world of the komiks. Gilda Olvidado (b. 1957) and Nerissa Cabral (b. 1943) will follow in her footsteps.

media_caption: Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa by Dominador Mirasol, 1975, Social realist literature
text_description: Sagisag begins serialization of Dominador Mirasol’s (1940-2003) Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa, notable for its lucid depiction of the continuing struggles of Filipino peasants.

media_caption: Rolando S. Tinio, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1997
text_description: Rolando Tinio (1937-97) publishes Kristal na Uniberso, which marks the poet’s return to the tradition of Philippine romantic poetry while still following the “bagay” school.
A Stun of Jewels by Carlos Angeles (1921-2001), the first collection to receive the Palanca in poetry, is published.
The first Bagay poems, characterized by colloquial language and concrete imagery—qualities which represent a break from the Balagtas tradition—appear in the Ateneo de Manila campus journal Heights.
The Ilonggo short story anthology Bahandi I: 46 ka Pili nga mga Sugilanon sa Ilonggo is published, the stories therein mostly taken from Hiligaynon between 1960 and 1970.
The UBOD New Authors series of the NCCA is launched, allowing new voices using the vernaculars to be heard.

media_caption: Founding members of the Ilocano writers’ group GUMIL-Filipinas
text_description: Gumil Filipinas is formally organized, four years after the formation of Gumil Ilocos Sur, the first provincial organization of Ilocano writers.

“Maria, ang Iyong Anak” by Wilfredo Virtusio (1942-92), about a mother and her activist son during the height of student activism in the late 1960s and early 1970s, is published. Virtusio’s collected stories Bilanggo at Iba pang Akda will be published in 1992.
Wallace Stegner visits the Philippines.

media_caption: Virgilio S. Almario, awarded National Artist for literature in 2003
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Walong Dekada ng Makabagong Tulang Pilipino, edited by Virgilio Almario (b. 1944), is published, an anthology of poems between 1900 and 1980 by 45 poets.

media_caption: Kurditan: Mga Kuwentong Iluko, edited by Reynaldo A. Duque, Jose A. Bragado, and Linda T. Lingbaoan,1988, Collection of short stories by various Ilocano writers
text_description: The first anthology of translations in Filipino of Ilocano stories, Kurditan: Mga Kwentong Iluko (Canvas: Ilocano Stories), is published, containing 30 short stories.

media_caption: Regional literature reprinted with translation in Filipino
text_description: A translation by Edgardo B. Maranan and Nicole Revel-Macdonald of the Palawan epic Kudaman, as chanted by Usuy, is published.

media_caption: Cubao 1980 at iba pang mga katha by Tony Perez, 1992, Gay literature in the 1990s
text_description: Cubao 1980, the first in Tony Perez’s Cubao series, notable for its depiction of the lives of gay men, is published.

media_caption: Killing time in a Warm Place by Jose Y. Dalisay, Jr., 1992, Realist novel in English
text_description: “Killing Time in a Warm Place” by Jose Dalisay (b. 1954) and “Subanons” by Antonio Enriquez (b. 1936) share the Palanca Grand Prize for the novel in English. The novels will be published in 1992 and 1999, respectively.

media_caption: Ladlad, 1994, an anthology of gay literature edited by J. Neil C. Garcia and Danton Remoto
text_description: The first of the Ladlad anthologies, which gather together contemporary gay literature, is published, with J. Neil Garcia (b. 1969) and Danton Remoto (b. 1963) as editors.

media_caption: Penmanship, Jose Dalisay Jr., 1995, Collection of short stories by various Ilocano writers
text_description: Jose Dalisay’s Penmanship and Other Stories, a showcase of the author’s mastery of the genre, is published.

media_caption: Carlos Quirino, awarded National Artist for literature in 1997
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Carlos Quirino (1910-99), author of a biography of Rizal, The Great Malayan, is declared National Artist for his historical writings.

media_caption: Levi Celerio, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1997
text_description: Levi Celerio (1910-2002) is declared National Artist in Music and Literature.

media_caption: Bienvenido Lumbera, awarded National Artist for literature in 2006
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Bienvenido Lumbera’s Likhang Dila, Likhang Diwa, which collects the author’s poems written between 1956 and 1992, is published.

The Radical Tradition in Philippine Literature by Epifanio San Juan Jr (b. 1938), which engages such figures as Amado V. Hernandez, Carlos Bulosan, Lope K. Santos, and Jose Ma. Sison (b.1939), from a Marxist perspective, is published.

media_caption: N. V. M. Gonzalez, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1997
text_description: N. V. M. Gonzalez is declared National Artist.

The Filipinos in the Philippines and Other Essays by nationalist historian Renato Constantino is published. It includes “The Miseducation of the Filipino,” which blames the teaching of English for the mental colonization by the United States of the Filipino.
Wilfrido Nolledo (1933-2004) publishes But for the Lovers, a tour de force of a novel set during World War II.

Panulat para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan (PAKSA), which champions national democratic literature for the masses, is officially organized at the Philippine College of Commerce (now Polytechnic University of the Philippines). The Paksa Workbook, a compilation of annotations and reviews of the works of art and literature of the national democratic movement from 1970 to 1971, is published.
The first in Budgette Tan’s Trese series of graphic novels, which situates local mythological creatures in the contemporary city, is published.

media_caption: Jose Rey Munsayac’s Ang Aso, ang Pulgas, ang Bonsai at ang Kolorum, first place in the Philippine Centennial Literary Prize in the Filipino novel category
text_description:
The winners of the Centennial Literary Contest, which will later be published by the University of the Philippines Press, are:
· “My Sad Republic” by Eric Gamalinda (novel in English)
· “Ang Aso, ang Pulgas, ang Bonsai at ang Kolorum” by Jose Reyes Munsayac and “Etsa-Puwera” by Jun Cruz Reyes (novel in Filipino)
· “Mujer Indigena” by V. E. Carmelo D. Nadera (poetry in Filipino)
· “Sunlight on Broken Stones” by Cirilo F. Bautista (poetry in English)
· “Candon” by Reynaldo Duque and “Piping-dilat” by Teo T. Antonio (epic)
· “The Spirit of 1896: A Mirror of the Philippine Past, a Mirror on the Nation’s Future” by Jason Co (essay)

media_caption: Muog: Ang Naratibo ng Kanayunan sa Matagalang Digmaang Bayan sa Pilipinas, UP Press, Anthology of activist literature during the martial law era
text_description: Muog, a multi-language anthology of narratives by cadres and other figures on the protracted armed communist struggle in the countryside, is published.

media_caption: Florentino Collantes, left, and Jose Corazon de Jesus, the most famous “kings” of balagtasan, ca 1930
text_description: Ang Tulisan at Iba pang Talinghaga by Florentino Collantes (1896-1951), a comprehensive collection of the author’s work, is published.

media_caption: Sa Labas ng Parlor, Honorio Bartolome de Dios, 1998, Gay literature in the 1990s
text_description: Honorio Bartolome de Dios’s Sa Labas ng Parlor, an account of the Filipino gay experience with a radical bent, is published.

media_caption: Smaller and smaller circles, F.H. Batacan, 2007 reprint
text_description: “Smaller and Smaller Circles” by Ma. Felisa H. Batacan wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English. It will be published nationally in 2002; revised and published in the United States in 2015. It will be made into a film in 2017.

media_caption: Edith L. Tiempo, awarded National Artist for literature in 1999
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Edith L. Tiempo is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Caroline Hau, Chinese-Filipino writer
text_description: Intsik: An Anthology of Chinese-Filipino writing, edited by Caroline Hau, is published. It will be translated into Chinese in 2003.
Dilim sa Umaga, a novel by Efren Abueg, is published.

media_caption: Nick Joaquin, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1976
text_description: Nick Joaquin is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Members of the Davao Writers’ Guild
text_description: The Davao Writers Guild is organized, with Don Pagusara as its first president.

media_caption: Sarilaysay: Tinig ng 20 Babae sa Sariling Danas Bilang Manunulat, 2000
text_description: Rosario Torres-Yu’s (b.1949) Sarilaysay, an inquiry into the consciousness of woman writers via storytelling sessions with 20 writers, is published. It will be followed in 2004 by a companion volume of interviews with male writers.

Twenty Cebuano writers, including Ernesto Lariosa (b. 1944), Temistokles Adlawan (1930-2009), Junne Canizares (b. 1936), Ricardo Patalinjug (b. 1945), and Rene Amper (1940-2007), found Bathalad, a major association of writers in Cebuano.

media_caption: Doctrina Christiana en la Lengua Española y Tagala, 1593
text_description: The Doctrina Christiana is published. It is the first book in Spanish and Tagalog printed in the Philippines using woodblocks, which is similar to Chinese xylographic printing.

media_caption: F. Landa Jocano, right, recording Hugan-an chanting the Hinilawod in the mountains of Central Panay. ca 1955
media_credit: (Hinilawod: Adventures of Humadapnon [Tarangban I], PUNLAD Research House, 2000)
text_description: A translation by F. Landa Jocano (1930-2003) of the Panay epic Hinilawod, as chanted by Ulang Uding in 1964, is published.

media_caption: F. Sionil Jose, awarded National Artist for literature in 2001
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: F. Sionil Jose is declared National Artist.

media_caption: The Sky Over Dimas, Vicente Garcia Groyon, 2003, Novel with social and historical themes
text_description: “The Sky over Dimas” by Vicente Garcia Groyon wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English. It will be published in 2003.

media_caption: Tuwaang Atteds a Wedding, E. Arsenio Manuel, 1975, Text of Philippine epics in book form
text_description: E. Arsenio Manuel’s pioneering “A Survey of Philippine Epics” is published in Asian Folklore Studies. Manuel’s transcriptions and studies of the Ilianon and the Manobo epics result in such publication as The Maiden of the Buhong Sky (1958), Agyu (1969), and Tuwaang Attends a Wedding (1975).

media_caption: The Firewalkers, Erwin E. Castillo, 1992, Work of metafiction
text_description: Erwin Castillo’s (b. 1950) novel Firewalkers, a whirlwind tour of Philippine history through the mythical Cavite town Lakambaga, is published.

media_caption: Virgilio S. Almario, awarded National Artist for literature in 2003
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Virgilio S. Almario is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Mga Tulang tulala, Kristian Sendon Cordero, 2004, Filipino poetry in Bikol
media_credit: (National Commission for Culture and the Arts and Goldprint Publishing House)
text_description: Kristian Cordero’s (b. 1983) Mga Tulang Tulala, a collection of poems in Filipino, Bicol, and Rinconada, is published.

media_caption: Salamanca, Dean Francis Alfar, 2006, Work of metafiction
text_description: “Salamanca” by Dean Francis Alfar (b. 1969) wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English.
Indigenous ways of writing flourish.
Ulahingan: An Epic of the Southern Philippines by Elena Maquiso is published.
The Manila Critics’ Circle, responsible for the annual National Book Awards, is founded, giving out the first awards in 1982.
Akademyang Bikol, an organization intended to develop, standardize, and promote the Bikol language, is founded in Naga City.

media_caption: STR, Mga Tula ng Digmaang Bayan sa Pilipinas, Anthology of activist literature during the martial law era
text_description: STR, mga Tula ng Digmang Bayan sa Pilipinas brings to the surface underground poetry from various sectors and regions.

media_caption: The Trilogy of Saint Lazarus by Cirilo F. Bautista, Philippine poetry in English
text_description: Cirilo Bautista’s (b. 1941) epic poem The Trilogy of Saint Lazarus, which maps out the country’s history from precolonial times to after the EDSA Revolt, is published.

The first of Leopoldo Yabes’s (1912-86) landmark three-volume anthology Philippine Short Stories, covering the 1920s to the early 1950s, is published. The next two volumes will be published in 1981. Between 2009 and 2014 Gemino Abad (b. 1939) will extend the scope of Yabes’s anthologies to the twenty-first century.
Sea Serpent, the first book of poems by Alfred Yuson (b. 1945), is published.
The Philippine Literary Arts Council (PLAC) is established.

Jun Cruz Reyes (b. 1947) publishes his first short story collection, Utos ng Hari at Iba pang Kuwento. The title story, with its colloquialisms and irreverence, has come to epitomize youthful anti-establishment."

Saturnino Apoyon’s (b. 1935) Ang Gakit ni Noebong ug Ubang mga Sugilanon, a sympathetic chronicle of the lives of indigenous Bagobo and Tiruray tribes, the Badjao sea gypsies, and barrio folk and city folk, is published.

media_caption: Davao Harvest, Ricardo M. de Ungria, Tita Lacambra Ayala, 2008, Regional literature of the new millennium
media_credit: (National Commission for Culture and the Arts)
text_description: Davao Harvest, which collects literary works and visual art by writers and artists in and from Davao, is published.

media_caption: State of War by Ninotchka Rosca, 1988, Socially oriented work in English
text_description: Ninotchka Rosca (b. 1946) publishes the magic realist novel A State of War, which covers 400 years of Philippine history.

media_caption: Bienvenido Lumbera, awarded National Artist for literature in 2006
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Bienvenido Lumbera is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Ilustrado by Miguel Syjuco, Book of fiction with allegorical themes
text_description: “Ilustrado” by Miguel Syjuco wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English. It will win the Man Asian Literary Prize and be published in 2010.
Temistokles Adlawan’s Ang Kabaho, Unya ang Kahumot sa Pulbos, notable for capturing the polyphonic registers of Cebuano, serialized in Bisaya.

media_caption: Mga Ibong Mandaragit by Amado V. Hernandez, 1959, Social realist novel
text_description: Liwayway begins serialization of Mga Ibong Mandaragit by Amado V. Hernandez (1903-70), noted for its lucid analysis of the nature of class conflict in city and country.

media_caption: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Zsazsa Zaturnnah: Ze Muzikal, 2011, a stage adaptation of Carlo Vergara’s graphic novel Ang Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah
text_description: Carlo Vergara’s (b. 1971) graphic novel Ang Kagilagilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah, helps revive the local komiks industry.

media_caption: At the 2012 Talaang Ginto Gawad Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino sa Tula, with Bicol-based poet Jose Jason Chancoco, fourth from left, receiving his prize
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Jose Jason L. Chancoco)
text_description: Pagsasatubuanan: Poetikang Bikolnon by Jason Chancoco, the first book-length study of the rawitdawit or Bikol poetry, is published.

media_caption: Lazaro Francisco, awarded National Artist for literature in 2009
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Lazaro Francisco is declared National Artist.

media_caption: Cirilo F. Bautista, awarded National Artist for literature in 2014
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Cirilo F. Bautista is declared National Artist.
Voltaire Oyzon’s An Maupay ha mga Waray ug Iba pa nga mga Siday, which marks a new contemporary direction for the Waray poetic form siday, is published.
Victor Sugbo’s Inintokan, with poems in Waray that chronicle the author’s journey through his native homeland, is published.
Batbat hi Udan by Telesforo Sungkit, a novel that uses the devices of the epic, is published.
Philippine Folk Literature, the first in a pioneering series of anthologies of folk literature edited by Damiana Eugenio (1921-2014), is published.
“Gerilya” by Norman Wilwayco wins the Palanca.
“In the Service of Secrets” by Marivi Soliven wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English.

media_caption: Men of the East, Charlson Ong, 1999, Collection of short stories by various Ilocano writers
text_description: Charlson Ong (b. 1960) publishes Men of the East and Other Stories, an examination of the Chinese-Filipino experience.

media_caption: Liwayway A. Arceo, Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Panitikan) awardee in 1993
media_credit: (CCP Collection, BJ Patiño, and Ricardo Lee/Jerry Siapoc)
text_description: Liwayway starts the column “Bagong Dugo,” edited by Liwayway Arceo, featuring short stories by new writers, advancing the development of modern Tagalog fiction. The column will last until Jan 1963.
“Vaya con Virgo” by Wilfrido D. Nolledo wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English.
Pambansang Unyon ng mga Manunulat, or Panulat, which advocates the welfare of writers and undertakes grassroots-writing workshops, is founded.
On the occasion of the bicentenary of Balagtas, the CCP publishes Himalay Balagtas, a collection of historical and critical studies on the poet. It will publish Himalay Rizal in 1991.
“Ang Banal na Aklat ng Mga Kumag” by Allan Derain wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.
Resil Mojares’s (b. 1943) Origins and Rise of the Filipino Novel is published.

The Writer and His Milieu, an oral history of Filipino writers in English by Edilberto N. Alegre (1938-2009) and Doreen G. Fernandez (1934-2002), is published. The second volume, Writers and Their Milieu, will be published in 1987.
Merlie Alunan’s (b. 1943) Pagdakop sg Bulalakaw ug Uban pang Mga Balak, the author’s first book of Cebuano poetry and which includes equally masterful English translations, is published.
Vicente Rafael (b. 1956) publishes Contracting Colonialism, notable for its pioneering reading of early Tagalog society’s experience of Christian conversion.
Teo Antonio (b. 1946) publishes Taga sa Bato, a showcase of his wide repertoire of styles and material.

media_caption: Alejandro Roces, awarded National Artist for literature in 2003
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer, Philippine Star, NCCA, and De La Salle University)
text_description: Of Cocks and Kites, a collection of humorous stories by Alejandro Roces (1924-2011) is published.

media_caption: Bamboo in the Wind by Azucena Grajo Uranza, 1990, Realist novel in English
text_description: “Bamboo in the Wind” by Azucena Grajo Uranza (1929-2012) wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel. It is published in the same year.
Ruth Elynia S. Mabanglo (b. 1949) publishes Kung Di Man, a collection of love poems that foreground female desire.
Adonis Durado’s (b. 1975) Minugbo Alang sa Mugbo og Kalipay, with poems written in indigenous Cebuano forms like garay and tigmo but using modern material, is published.
The anthology Tinigpigan, edited by Victor Sugbo, is published and brings the works of Waray poets past and present Trinchera, Lucente, Makabenta, and de Veyra in book form.

media_caption: Francisco Arcellana, awarded National Artist for Literature in 1990
text_description: Francisco Arcellana is declared National Artist.

Man of Earth, the first volume, coedited by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz, in Gemino Abad’s comprehensive anthology of Philippine poetry in English is published where he expounds on “writing from English.” The other two volumes are A Native Clearing (1993) and A Habit of Shores (1999).
“Bulaklak ng Maynila” by Domingo G. Landicho (b. 1939); and “Moog” by Buenaventura S. Medina Jr (b. 1929) share the Palanca Grand Prize for the novel in Filipino.

Ali*Bang+Bang Atbp. Kwento by Rolando Tolentino (b. 1964) and Pitada by Eli Guieb (b. 1962) are published as one volume, marking the emergence of a new generation of technically innovative Tagalog fictionists.
Albay Viejo by Raffi Banzuela (b. 1951), a collection of essays, historical narratives, and short stories on Albay, is published.
“Tatlong Gabi, Tatlong Araw” by Eros Atalia wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.

media_caption: Collection of socially committed poetry in Tagalog by Lamberto E. Antonio, 1980
text_description: Hagkis ng Talahib, the first poetry collection of Lamberto Antonio (b. 1946), is published.
Bathalad-Mindanao, an offshoot of Bathalad that seeks to distinguish their “Bisaya” language from Cebu-based Cebuano, is formed in Cagayan de Oro.
The first of the Twisted books Jessica Zafra (b. 1965), compilations of her columns, is printed, representing the sensibility of a generation.
Francisco Macansantos’s Balsa: Poemas Chabacanos is published.
The first literary works in English of the pensionado are published in the Filipino Students’ Magazine.
The first volume of Sugidanon of Panay, by Alice Magos, is published.

media_caption: Gregorio Brillantes, post-World War II writer in English
text_description: The Distance to Andromeda and Other Stories by Gregorio Brillantes (b. 1932) is published. It includes “Faith, Love, Time and Doctor Lazaro,” establishing him as a “Catholic writer.”

media_caption: The Woman Who Had Two Navels by Nick Joaquin, 1961, Novel in English
text_description: Nick Joaquin’s The Woman Who Had Two Navels, which explores the question of national identity and the ambiguity of good and evil, is published.

Diary ng Panget is published as a book after being serialized on the online platform Wattpad in 2011, epitomizing both a new form called pop fiction and a trend in literary reproduction, from digital to print media rather than vice versa. It will be adapted into a movie in 2014.

media_caption: Mga Agos sa Disyerto
media_credit: Book cover courtesy of C&E Publishing, Inc
text_description: Mga Agos sa Disyerto, containing the stories of Edgardo M. Reyes (1936-2012), Rogelio R. Sicat (1940-1997) Efren Abueg (b. 1937), Eduardo Bautista Reyes, and Rogelio Ordoñez (1940-2016), is published, ushering in modernism in the Tagalog short story.

media_caption: Front page of Diariong Tagalog
media_credit: (National Commission for  Culture and the Arts)
text_description: Diariong Tagalog, the first reformist newspaper, is founded by Marelo H. del Pilar (1850-96)

media_caption: Hiligaynon, 14 Apr 1954
text_description: Gregorio Sumcad’s social realist novel Sakada, noted for its accurate depiction of a migrant sugar worker’s life, begins serialization in Hiligaynon.

media_caption: An edition of Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang
text_description: The two-volume Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang is published. It collects the best and most popular of the Lola Basyang stories originally published in Liwayway,
Prosang Itim by Mike Bigornia (1950-2001), continuing the long local tradition of prose poetry, is published and becomes a bestseller.
“Recuerdo,” an epistolary novel by Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo (b. 1944), wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English. It is published in the same year.
“Ang Kaulayaw ng Agila” by Lilia Quindoza Santiago (b. 1949) wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.
A B N K K B S N P L A ko?!, a humorous take on school mores and social institutions by enigmatic author Bob Ong, breaks local publishing records.
“Kung Paano Ko Inayos ang Buhok Ko Matapos ang Mahaba-haba Ring Paglalakbay” by Norman Wilwayco wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.
“May Bagyo Ma’t Rilim,” the earliest published poem written by a native, is included in Memoria de la Vida Cristiana en Lengua Tagala, evincing the Christianization of the native mind.
“Malaybay” by Edmund Coronel wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.
High Chair, a group of poets and a small press known for what some describe as “high modernist” poetics, is formed.
Nick Joaquin (1917-2004) will commemorate the event in the essay “La Naval de Manila” and in the poem The Ballad of the Five Battles.
Aniceto de la Merced writes the third Filipino pasyon, El Libro de la Vida.
Pagbasa ng Panitikan at Kulturang Popular by Soledad Reyes (b. 1946), which collects her pioneering studies in Philippine popular culture, is published.
Knife’s Edge, which collects Edel Garcellano’s (b. 1946) Marxist critiques on local literary production and practices, is published.
Iloilo historian Pedro Monteclaro’s Maragtas, which purports to be a record of events in 13th-century Panay, is published. It inspires many, short stories, poems, and essays.
Beginning in 1925, the Philippines Herald will have a weekly magazine supplement where new stories and poems by Filipino writers using English are published.
Coming Home, which epitomizes Cristina Pantoja Hidalgo’s creative nonfiction, is published.

The first in a series of articles on historical events with social or patriotic interest, Efemerides Filipinas, is serialized in El Ideal, ostensibly to help in the formation of a Filipino consciousness.

Sanghiran san Binisaya, whose members include Jaime de Veyra (1873-1963), Iluminado Lucente (1883-1960), and Eduardo Makabenta (1885-1973), is founded by Norberto Romualdez (1875-1941), heralding the rise in vernacular publications in Leyte and Samar.

The Fundacion will hand out the first Premio Zobel in 1922 to Guillermo Gomez Windham (1880-1957) for La Carrera de Candida, through whose protagonist’s life he depicts the “moral harm” caused by Americanization.

media_caption: Cover of the original manuscript of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere, 1887
text_description: Jose Rizal publishes Noli me Tangere in Berlin, Germany. A few copies of the novel begin to arrive in the Philippines in two months.

media_caption: Pinaglahuan by Faustino Aguilar, 1907, Pre-World War II novels written in local languages
media_credit: (Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection and University of the Philippines Press)
text_description: The novel Pinaglahuan by Faustino Aguilar (1882-1955), which depicts the entry of American capitalism and forwards a radical structural change to transform society, is published.

media_caption: Reformist writer Jose Rizal
text_description: Rizal writes his last poem "Mi Ultimo Adios."

media_caption: Revolutionary writer Andres Bonifacio
text_description: Katipunan supremo Andres Bonifacio (1863-97) publishes "Pag-ibig sa Tinubuang Lupa" and "Ang Dapat Mabatid ng mga Tagalog" in Kalayaan.
With its celebration of the individual and use of free verse, the poem "Ako ang Daigdig" by Alejandro Abadilla breaks new ground in Tagalog poetry.

media_caption: Carlos P. Romulo, 1982, National Artists for Literature
text_description: Carlos P. Romulos (1899-1985) speech "I Am a Filipino" is published in the Philippines Herald. It will be a familiar oratorical piece in Philippine high schools.

media_caption: America is in the Heart by Carlos Bulosan, Carlos Bulosan’s poetry and fiction about the Filipino experience in the Philippines and the United States
text_description: America Is in the Heart by Carlos Bulosan (1913-56) is published in New York. In narrating the experiences of Filipino laborers in the United States, it will become a key text in Philippine-American and Asian American literature.

media_caption: Without Seeing the Dawn, Steven Javellana, 1998 reprint, Philippine novels in English
text_description: Without Seeing the Dawn by Stevan Javellana (1918-77), considered the most artistic and compelling narrative of the Filipino experience of World War II, is published in Boston.

media_caption: Marcelo H. del Pilar, Literary figures during the Spanish period
text_description: Marcelo H. del Pilar and friends publish Dasalan at Tocsohan, an antifriar parody of Catholic prayers and the catechism.
Liwanag at Dilim, a collection of aphoristic, lyrical essays by Emilio Jacinto (1875-99) on notions of liberty and equality, is published in Kalayaan.

Pasyon and Revolution by Reynaldo Ileto (b. 1946), an influential study on the link between the pasyon and the formation of a popular revolutionary consciousness and parallel movements like the Katipunan, is published.

media_caption: Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, Lilia Quindoza Santiago, Reuel Molina Aguila, Herminio S. Beltran, Jr., Anthologies of activist literature during the martial law era
text_description: The first of a series of anthologies (poetry, short story, drama) of the literature of protest in the Philippines, Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986 (Tula), is published by the CCP.

media_caption: SIGWA
media_credit: Book cover courtesy of University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Sigwa, containing Tagalog short stories by young and veteran writers who are involved in the political protest movement of the 1970s, is published.

media_caption: Bikol, Translation of the Tagalog Pasyong Genesis
text_description: The Pasyong Genesis or Casaysayan nang Mahal na Pasion, aka Pasyong Pilapil, after Mariano Pilapil, the censor who approved it, is published. It is the second and most popular of the Tagalog pasyon, credited for shaping the Christian Filipinos’ image of Jesus Christ. It is later translated into Ilocano, Kapampangan, Bicol, Ilonggo, Cebuano, and Waray, among other languages.

media_caption: A 1939 film adaptation of Florante at Laura, directed by Vicente Salumbides
text_description: Francisco Baltazar (1788-1863), aka Balagtas, writes and publishes Florante at Laura, the most famous awit in Philippine literary history. It is interpreted by many as the first example of protest literature in the Philippines.
Urbana at Feliza by Modesto de Castro (active 1864-87), a slim conduct book considered a precursor of the Tagalog novel, is published.

media_caption: La Solidaridad, 1895, the outlet for propagandist literature in the late 19th century
media_credit: (from the Jose Victor Z. Torres Collection)
text_description: Rizal’s essay “Sobre la Indolencia de los Filipinos” is published in La Solidaridad.

Liceo Artistico-Literario, a short-lived literary society, sponsors a literary contest. Rizal’s (1861-1896) “A la Juventud Filipina” and “El Consejo de los Dioses” receive prizes in 1879 and 1880, respectively.

media_caption: Apolinario Mabini, prime minister of the first Philippine republic
media_credit: (Colorized by the Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines)
text_description: Apolinario Mabini (1864-1903) writes “El Verdadero Decalogo,” enumerating the values that he thinks Filipinos should possess.

“Hibik nang Filipinas sa Inang España” by Hermenegildo Flores (d. 1896) and “Sagot nang España sa Hibik nang Filipinas” by del Pilar will appear together. The poems show the growing discontent among Filipinos with Spanish rule.

“Filipinas” by Jose Palma (1876-1903), which provided the lyrics for the national anthem “Himno Nacional Filipinas,” and “Al Heroe Nacional” by Cecilio Apostol (1877-1938) are published in La Independencia, to commemorate the death of Rizal. Other nationalistic pieces by Antonio Luna, Manuel Guerrero, and others appear in the newspaper.

text_headline: Ang Cababalaghan ni P. Bravo by Gabriel Beato Francisco (1850-1935) is serialized, the first Tagalog novel.
text_description: Ang Cababalaghan ni P. Bravo by Gabriel Beato Francisco (1850-1935) is serialized, the first Tagalog novel.

media_caption: Cover of Fray Miguel Lucio y Bustamante’s Si Tandang Basio Macunat, 1885, reprinted in 2005
text_description: Si Tandang Basio Macunat by Spanish friar Miguel Lucio Bustamante, which attacks liberal ideas, is published.

media_caption: Ninay by Pedro Paterno(novel), Cover of the Manila edition of Pedro Paterno’s novel
text_description: The first Filipino novel, Ninay: Costumbres Filipinas by Pedro Paterno (1857-1911), is published in Madrid.
Paolo Manalo’s poetry collection Jolography, with its novel use of Taglish, is published.

text_headline: “All My Lonely Islands” by Victorette Joy Z. Campilan wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English.
text_description: “All My Lonely Islands” by Victorette Joy Z. Campilan wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in English.

text_headline: “Toto O.” by Charmaine Mercader Lim wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.
text_description: “Toto O.” by Charmaine Mercader Lim wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.

text_headline: Diary ng Panget is published as a book after being serialized on the online platform Wattpad in 2011
text_description: Diary ng Panget is published as a book after being serialized on the online platform Wattpad in 2011, epitomizing both a new form called pop fiction and a trend in literary reproduction, from digital to print media rather than vice versa. It will be adapted into a movie in 2014.

text_headline: “Ang Banal na Aklat ng Mga Kumag” by Allan Derain wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.
text_description: “Ang Banal na Aklat ng Mga Kumag” by Allan Derain wins the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino.

text_headline: Albay Viejo by Raffi Banzuela (b. 1951), a collection of essays, historical narratives, and short stories on Albay, is published.
text_description: Albay Viejo by Raffi Banzuela (b. 1951), a collection of essays, historical narratives, and short stories on Albay, is published.
Pedro Bucaneg (1591-ca. 1626) transcribes Biag ti Lam-ang, the Ilocano epic.
The first contact between Spain and what would be the Philippines will inspire literary works such as Longitude by Carlos Cortes and the young adult novel Enrique El Negro by Carla Pacis.
Oral and indigenous literature of the peoples of the Philippines are created and passed on. This includes riddles, proverbs, tales, epics, and songs of different types.
Rosario Cruz Lucero’s (b. 1949) Feast and Famine, a collection of stories that deftly engage Negrense history and folklore, is published.
Zoilo Galang’s Kapampangan novel Ing Capalaran, which is distinguished for its use of Spanish and English words and sayings, Tagalog idioms, and humor, is published.
Romulo Baquiran’s (b. 1962) Onyx, a showcase of both modernist free verse and traditional forms, is published.
Filipino Poetry, the first anthology of Filipino poems in English, edited by Luis Dato (1906-1983), is published.
“Dead Stars” by Paz Marquez-Benitez (1894-1983), considered the first modern Philippine short story in English, appears in the Philippines Herald.
The weekly magazine supplement of Tribune publishes short stories by Filipino writers and will later sponsor a short story contest in 1927.

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Elena Gardoce, 1992
media_credit: (CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library, Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab)
text_description: Epic chanter Elena Gardoce is given the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.

media_caption: Niño Muhlach, Veronica Jones, and Vilma Santos in Darna at Ding, 1980.
text_description: Darna appears in Pilipino Komiks. It is one of many comic book creations of Mars Ravelo (1916-88), which include Dyesebel, Captain Barbell, and Lastikman. All will be adapted into successful movies and television shows.
Until 1943, Silew becomes the main publication venue of Pangasinan literature. Among its contributors will be Maria Magsano (1883-1969). It is followed by Sandi’y Silew in 1943.

media_caption: Serena Dalrymple, Vilma Santos, and Carlo Aquino in Chito Roño’s Bata, Bata ... Paano Ka Ginawa?, 1998
text_description: “Bata, Bata, Paano Ka Ginawa” by Lualhati Bautista and “Bata, Sinaksak, Isinilid sa Baul” by Tony Perez (b. 1951) share the Palanca Grand Prize for the Novel in Filipino. Written in Taglish, Bautista’s novel about a liberated woman’s predicaments in conventional society, will be published in 1988.

media_caption: National Artist Rolando S. Tinio
text_description: Rolando S. Tinio is declared National Artist in Literature and Theater.

media_caption: Tomas Pinpin’s Librong Pagaaralan nang manga Tagalog nang Uicang Castila, originally published in 1610, and reprinted in 2011
text_description: Tomas Pinpin (ca. 1580-ca. 1670) prints Librong Pagaaralan nang manga Tagalog nang Uicang Castila, which contains samples of ladino poetry or poems alternating Tagalog lines with Spanish ones.

media_caption: Title page of Fr Gaspar de San Agustin’s Compendio del Arte de la Lengua Tagala, 1870
text_description: Compendio del Arte de la Lengua Tagala by Fray Gaspar de San Agustin records the first statement of literary criticism made by a native: “Magaling, datapoa hindi tola.”

media_caption: 2013 reprint of Juan de Noceda and Pedro de Sanlucar’s Vocabulario de la Lengua Tagala, originally published in 1754
text_description: Vocabulario de la Lengua Tagala by Juan de Noceda and Pedro de Sanlucar is published. It contains samples of early Tagalog poetry, including the tanaga.

The Sunday literary supplement (begun in 1929) of Makinaugalingon will carry the writings of Miguela Montelibano (1874-1969) and the “trinidad poetica Ilonga”: Flavio Zaragoza Cano (1862-1964), Delfin Gumban (b. 1890), and Serapion Torre (1892-1942).

“The Small Key” by Paz Latorena appears in the Philippines Herald. This and other stories of hers that explore the female psyche, like “Desire” and “Sunset” will be collected in Desire and Other Stories in 2000.
Deogracias Rosario’s “Ako’y Mayroong Isang Ibon,” regarded as the first “plotless” Tagalog short story, is published. His stories will be collected in Deogracias A. Rosario 1894-1936 in 1995.
Loreto Paras-Sulit publishes “Harvest,” whose opening line has become a classic, is published in the Philippines Herald. Her stories will be collected in Harvest and Other Stories in 2001.

media_caption: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Ang Mga Huwad, Rody Vera’s stage adaptation of F. Sionil Jose’s The Pretenders, CCP, Manila, 2007
text_description: The Pretenders, the first in five-novel Rosales Saga by F. Sionil Jose (b. 1924), chronicling the life of the Samson clan through upheavals in Philippine history, is published.

media_caption: Lope K. Santos’s Banaag at Sikat
text_description: Muling Pagsilang begins serialization of Banaag at Sikat by Lope K. Santos (1879-1963), widely considered as the first Tagalog novel imbued with an emergent socialist consciousness and working class ideology.

media_caption: Scene from Sari and Kiri Dalena’s docudrama Ang Kababaihan ng Malolos, 2014
text_description: Rizal sends a letter to “the women of Malolos,” which praises them for their desire for education and defines Rizal’s “ideal” woman.

media_caption: Cover of Bisaya
text_description: Bisaya becomes an outlet for Cebuano literature. Among its contributors will be Marcel Navarra (1914-84), Godofredo Roperos (b. 1930), Vicente Rama (1887-1956), and Maria Kabigon (1868-1962).
